awd_abstract_narration:
The objective of this proposal is to assist students, early-career researchers and instructors with travel fellowships to attend the FORCE11's Scholarly Communications Institute (FSCI) 2018 meeting being  held July 30 - August 3, 2018 at the University of California, San Diego. The intent of FSCI 2018 is to expose all participants to exceptional training opportunities and the latest research and trends in the ongoing transformation of scholarly communications and research practice and dissemination. In addition to special training sessions, participants will particularly benefit from increased access to principal role models within the field from prominent national and international research laboratories and centers.

The host organization, FORCE11, the Future of Research Communication and eScholarship, is a community of 2500+ scholars, librarians, archivists, publishers and research funders that help facilitate the change toward improved knowledge creation and sharing. Individually and collectively, the members bring about a change in modern scholarly communications through the effective use of information technology.  The FSCI 2018 meeting is designed as a week-long summer training meeting, incorporating intensive courses, seminars, workshops, group activities, lectures and hands-on training. Participants will attend courses taught by world-wide leading experts in scholarly communications.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The FORCE11 Scholarly Communications Institute (FSCI) was held at the University of California, San Diego July 30 to August 3, 2018. The NSF funding provided travel support for 24 speakers, researchers and students from the US to attend a week-long training dedicated to new and emerging topics in research communication and data management.  Topics included research ethics, FAIR Data management, rigor and responsibility, and measuring impact on new publishing technologies and forms of participating in Open Research.

The FSCI is an annual event launched by the FORCE11 community to present courses and workshops focussed on the latest trends, tools, and requirements for participating in Open Research.  

The Future of Research and E-scholarship (FORCE11) community was formed in 2011 to address rapidly changing advancements in scientific practices. This cross-domain, cross-discipline community of global researchers, librarians, publishers, technologists, funders, and administrators has made significant strides in this area having produced some of the following leading-edge initiatives. 

  • FAIR Data Principles

  • Joint Declaration of Data Citation Principle (JDDCP)

  • RRIDs (Research Resource Identifiers)

  • Software Citation Principles

  • Data Citation Principles Pilot Project

  • Annotating All Knowledge Coalition

  • Scholarly Commons

 

The 2018 FSCI courses covered new and emerging topics in research communication including:   

  • FAIR and Flexible Research Communication: Authoring Beyond PDF & Word
  • The Scholarly Commons
  • Community, Collaboration, and Impact: Open Scholarly Communication for HSS
  • Building an Open and Information-Rich Research Institution
  • Data in the Scholarly Communications Life Cycle
  • The Basics and Beyond: Developing a Critical, Community-Based Approach to Open Education
  • Research Reproducibility
  • The Art of Transforming a Research Paper into a Lay Summary
  • Open South: The Open Science Experience in Latin America and the Caribbean
  • Pre and post-publication peer review: perspectives and platforms
  • Detection of questionable publishing practices: procedures, key elements, and practical examples
  • Open Data Viz - Tools and Techniques to better report data
  • PART 1 - Integrating Wikidata with your research and curation workflows
  • How much does open access cost?
  • Publish reproducible code and data: a hands-on, bring-your-own-code course
  • Opening the Research Enterprise: Partnering to Support Openness in Grant-Funded Faculty Research
  • Walking the Walk: Promoting and maintaining best practices in fair and open evaluation
  • Implementing Software Citation
  • Mentoring the Next Generation of Open Scholars: Approaches, Tools, & Tactics

  • Structural Biology: A Prototypical Case for Publishing Big Data

This event inspires those attending to participate in the FORCE11 community and to positively impact others in their organization or country which in turn impacts society at large.  

The following are a sampling of comments from scholarship recipients.

  • This was an intense but very worthwhile week. I learned a lot and felt privileged to be among so many people who are change-makers at their institutions. It was inspiring. I will return to take advantage of classes that I didn't have time for this first time around.

  • I am now able to share with authors how to link to their own DOI’s and the range of file formats and to explain the multiple uses of a pre-print server (including using this to secure public input).

  • After informal exchanges at FSCI, I'm organizing a workshop for our graduate students on the subject of academic online presence.

  • My technical and programming skills have increased. I could install packages in R, crawl ORCID ID, Clean data, etc. I can upload a dataset, assign access permission among others in Dataverse. 

  • FSCI  was a wonderful learning-intensive experience. I went away with great strategies to share with our university, friends, colleagues and fellow students about how to build my research profile, register DOIs for data and how and why FAIR matters. The instructors were excellent and everyone was friendly. I would recommend FSCI as a place to learn and stay current at any level and for strategies on how to care for the masses of data that we are producing.”

  • "Overall I had a really positive experience at FSCI and I thank the programming and organizing committees and all those from UCSD who made this such a great experience. It was fantastic to come together with this group of individuals all focused on scholarly communication which is my work focus."

  • I learned a lot and loved the atmosphere. The campus was great, and the small class sizes were really nice for getting to know people. I am very glad to have all the course materials available to me. I am putting some of the knowledge I gained to use immediately. It is clear that a lot of thought goes into putting this learning opportunity together.

  • Outside of the courses, the Institute event offered rich opportunities for conversation and networking with individuals from different disciplines and backgrounds. Overall, my takeaway from FSCI18 was extremely valuable.

  • FSCI gave me an opportunity to network, develop practical skills, and perhaps, most importantly,  it shifted the way that I view library-faculty-student-researcher relationships because of FSCI's global and interdisciplinary nature.

Modified by: Maryann Martone
